In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Sure! Here is the implementation of your request in Julia:
```julia
function wrap_string(str::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(str, " ")
    result = ""
    for word in words
        if length(result) + length(word) > text_width - 1
            result *= "\n"
        elseif !isempty(result)
            result *= " "
        end
        result *= word
    end
    return result
end

str = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Cras pulvinar."
@show wrap_string(str)
```
This `wrap_string` function splits the input string into an array of words and then iterates over these words. If the length of the current result string plus the length of the next word would exceed the maximum width, it adds a newline character (`\n`) to the end of the result string before adding the new word. If the result string is not empty, it adds a space between the current word and the previous result string. Finally, it returns the resulting string.
The `@show` macro is used to print out the returned value from `wrap_string(str)`, which will be the string wrapped over multiple lines if necessary.
